key_points: Colin Powell, the first Black secretary of state and a retired four-star general, died at age 84.
Powell died of complications from COVID-19 despite being fully vaccinated, his family announced.
His family thanked the medical staff at Walter Reed National Medical Center for their care.
Powell made history in 2001 as the highest-ranking Black public official in the U.S.
During his confirmation hearing, Powell highlighted his appointment as evidence of American potential.
Tributes poured in on Twitter from politicians, analysts, and celebrities alike.
Stacey Abrams, April Ryan, DNC Chair Jaime Harrison, and George Takei were among those who expressed their condolences.
Powell served as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff before becoming Secretary of State.
He is remembered for leading with integrity, promoting democracy, and breaking racial barriers.
He is survived by his wife, Alma Vivian Powell, and three children.
